newsitem.title: UK: US and European bourses progress, dollar mixed.
newsitem.headline: US and European bourses progress, dollar mixed.

text.p: Wall Street and European bourses made progress on Wednesday, putting aside their worries over future prospects for now.

The New York stock market, the world's largest, had rebounded on Tuesday after U.S. interest rates were held steady and it rose a further 0.6 percent in morning business Wednesday, aided by higher bond prices.
Strength in shares of computer giant IBM and other recently shaky high technology stocks provided support.
On the foreign exchanges, the pound took centre stage, gaining ground after news of a 95,800 drop in British unemployment last month -- the biggest fall on record.

The dollar was boosted against the mark after a slowdown in German money supply growth left faint hopes for a cut in the key German money rate. But it was weaker against the yen after the first rise in Japan's trade surplus for two years.

Share trading in London, Europe's busiest stock market, was spiced with a little takeover bid speculation after news of an agreed 1.267 billion pound ($2.1 billion) bid by U.S. group Entergy for London Electricity.
The FTSE 100 index of key British shares gained 38.6 points to 4,018.2, topping 4,000 for the first time in five days.
Activity quickened despite the proximity of Christmas holidays, although most fund managers had seemed ready to wait until the New Year before rejigging portfolios, traders said.
"The bid this morning created thoughts of more money coming into the system," said one trader. "Coupled with Wall Street it was good enough to give us the momentum to get up to 4,000."

London shares shrugged off news that British November unemployment fell 95,800 to 1.93 million and retail sales rose 0.7 percent rather than a forecast 0.5 -- strong data that spurred fears of higher interest rates. This did, however, jolt the bond market although it later recovered.
"(It is) very strong data which will certainly increase pressure on the Chancellor(of Exchequer Kenneth Clarke) to increase rates," said Andrew Snowball, economist at the Cooperative Bank.
French shares held on to their gains to close higher, aided by strength on Wall Street, and traders were moderately optimistic about further gains.
German stocks ended bourse dealings with modest gains, also encouraged by Wall Street, a firmer dollar -- good news for exporters -- and weaker-than-expected German money supply data.
The Bundesbank said growth in its main monetary policy indicator, M3 money supply, slowed to an annualised rate of 8.0 percent in November from 8.4 percent in October.

Few analysts expect a German interest rate cut just now but they said the Bundesbank might shave rates as it often fixes its key repo rate over the year-end holiday period and could do so at a slightly lower rate than the current 3.0 percent.
Currency markets, pondering the chances of a surprise move by the German central bank, boosted the dollar against the mark.
"The M3 data was just soft enough to keep interest in Thursday's meeting alive," said one trader at a British bank.
The Bundesbank central council meets for the last time this year on Thursday and is set to announce its 1997 M3 growth targets at a news conference afterwards.

"I'd be very surprised (if the Bundesbank cut). The only thing that gives you a slight nag is the fact we've had France and a couple of other countries move. It has been suggested that perhaps there are some concerted ideas around," said Peter Wood, trader at Bank of Boston.

The Bank of France trimmed its key intervention rate to 3.15 percent from 3.20 on Tuesday, since then French call money has eased to 3-3/16 5/16 from 3-1/4 3/8, giving hope of more rate reductions, analysts said.
CURRENCIES AT THE EUROPEAN CLOSE
The dollar was quoted around 1.5543 marks and 113.62 yen, compared with 1.5454 and 113.73 in late business on Monday.
The pound rallied to 2.6002 marks from 2.5845.
STOCK MARKETS AT THE EUROPEAN CLOSE
London's FTSE 100 index ended 38.6 points higher at 4,018.2.
In Frankfurt, the 30-share DAX ended floor trade up 5.62 at 2,820.75 but slipped to 2,814.23 in later electronic business. In Paris, the CAC-40 share index finished up 25.19 at 2,218.89.
PRECIOUS METALS
Gold ended London trading at $369.10 after an afternoon fix of $368.70 and a previous close of $368.95. Silver was one cent lower at $4.86.
